blocks.value: Original Article: Organisation and Delivery of Care A randomized trial investigating the 12-month changes in physical activity and health outcomes following a physical activity consultation delivered by a person or in written form in Type 2 diabetes: Time2Act

Background and aims Physical activity is a cornerstone of Type 2 diabetes management but is underutilized. Physical activity consultations increase physical activity in people with Type 2 diabetes but resources are often limited. Time2Act is a randomized control trial to study the 12-month effectiveness of a physical activity consultation delivered by a person or in written form, in contrast to standard care, for people with Type 2 diabetes.
Methods A total of 134 inactive people with Type 2 diabetes in a contemplation or preparation stage were randomized to either intervention or standard care. Objective (accelerometer) and subjective (7-day recall) physical activity levels were measured over 1 week, along with physiological [blood pressure, body mass index (BMI), waist circumference] and biochemical [glycated haemoglobin (HbA 1c ), total and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol] measures at baseline, 6 and 12 months.
Results Neither a physical activity consultation delivered by a person nor in written form was better than standard care at increasing physical activity levels or improving health outcomes in the full study cohort. Total and HDL cholesterol, waist circumference and both systolic and diastolic blood pressure improved over 12 months in all groups, whilst HbA 1c improved over 6 months. Ina subgroup (baseline pedometer steps < 5000 ⁄ day), the physical activity consultation delivered by a person significantly increased physical activity over 12 months and the standard care group significantly decreased.
Conclusions More research is needed which not only investigates the most economical and effective methods to promote physical activity, but also the best setting to conduct physical activity consultations and the participant factors affecting uptake of physical activity in Type 2 diabetes.

Physical activity is a cornerstone of Type 2 diabetes management which improves cardiovascular risk factors and reduces hyperglycaemia independent of change in body weight.
Physical activity as simple as walking can decrease mortality risk in people with Type 2 diabetes. Unfortunately, people with Type 2 diabetes are substantially less likely to meet physical activity guidelines compared with the general population.
Individually adapted health behaviour change programmes that teach behavioural skills for self-management have been recommended because of their effectiveness in promoting physical activity. These behavioural approaches often use the transtheoretical model as a guide and include key elements such as goal setting, social support, problem solving and relapse prevention. They individually explore solutions rather than impose recommendations. In line with this approach, physical activity consultations have emerged as a successful strategy for the promotion of physical activity in people with Type 2 diabetes. Guidelines on conducting this intervention have been published for use in people with Type 2 diabetes. Brief advice approaches to physical activity promotion during routine practice use minimal resources but have not provided evidence of long-term effectiveness. Consultations have been successful but can be time intensive, lasting around 30 min, to include relevant behaviour change components. This requires greater resources such as time and money which limits widespread implementation into practice.
Finding intervention strategies which are effective in promoting physical activity with minimal time involved for healthcare providers should be explored. Promising strategies have emerged using both web-based and print materials to increase physical activity levels and reduce glycated haemoglobin (HbA 1c ) in people with Type 2 diabetes over 3 months, providing an indication that cost-effective strategies can be successful in the short term.
Time2Act is a randomized control trial comparing the effectiveness of two methods of physical activity promotion for people with Type 2 diabetes, in contrast to standard care. Participants were randomized to receive a physical activity consultation delivered by a person or in written form to increase physical activity levels over 6 and 12 months. Secondary aims were to investigate the resultant effects on glycaemic control, lipid profile, blood pressure, body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference. Change in medication was also monitored.

Figure illustrates the flow of participants through the study. Recruitment methods included: media adverts; diabetes clinics, general practitioner, university newsletters and diabetes exercise ⁄ education programmes.
The study sample characteristics are illustrated in Table. All participants were in the contemplation or preparation stage of behaviour change at baseline. The Tayside Committee on Medical Research Ethics, Scotland, approved all study procedures.

The ActiGraph GT1M accelerometer (ActiGraph LLC, Pensacola, FL, USA) was used to measure weekly step counts and body accelerations per min. Accelerometers were worn at waist level above the knee on the right side for 7 days during waking hours.
Seven-day physical activity recall A 7-day physical activity recall was conducted to measure subjective physical activity using a structured interview. Time spent in moderate, hard and very hard intensity activities were recorded.

Blood samples for HbA 1c , total cholesterol and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol were collected. If a sample could not be drawn, the closest available sample was used within 90 days when feasible.
No significant changes were recorded between groups at 6 or 12 months in diabetes medication, cholesterol medication or blood pressure medication (P > 0.05).

Using International Society for the Advancement of Kinanthropometry (ISAK) standards of anthropometric measurement, waist circumference was measured using anthropometric tape while standing. BMI was calculated using weight (kg) ⁄ height (m 2 ).

Both systolic and diastolic blood pressure measurements were taken after a period of rest in a seated position with a calibrated electronic monitor, OMRON M5-1 (Omron Healthcare, Tokyo Japan). Three measurements were taken and an average used.

Each participant came to the University fora maximum of six visits. All participants were sent study details and screened for eligibility. A letter was sent to their general practitioner regarding study participation.
During visit 1 a blood sample was obtained and body composition measurements taken. After completing questionnaire items, blood pressure was recorded. An accelerometer was attached and participants were given a physical activity diary to complete. After 7 days, participants returned for visit 2 where accelerometers were collected and the 7-day recall was conducted. All participants were then allocated to one of three groups: group 1, person delivered physical activity consultation; group 2, written delivered physical activity consultation; group 3, standard care. Visits 1 and 2 were repeated at 6 and 12 months.

Participants were randomly assigned on an individual basis using consecutively numbered sealed envelopes. A slight discrepancy in group allocation occurred resulting in uneven group numbers at baseline; however, subsequent power calculations identified that a minimum of 27 participants in each group was required for final analysis. This target was achieved. Researchers conducting outcome measures were blind to group allocation at baseline and inmost cases at 6 and 12 months.

Both intervention groups were given the same material (written physical activity pack). These groups differed only in the mode of intervention delivery. Participants assigned to the group fora physical activity consultation delivered by a person received a 30-min one-to-one consultation with a trained researcher based on successful strategies carried out by Kirk et al. and following published guidelines. The written physical activity packs described below were given to participants and used by the researcher to discuss relevant topics during the consultation at both baseline and 6 months. Participants assigned to the physical activity consultation delivered in written form group were simply given the written physical activity pack and encouraged to work through this in their own time.

At baseline, the physical activity pack included a written selfinstructional workbook based on the transtheoretical model of behaviour change, designed for people in the contemplation or preparation stages of change. It contained content traditionally discussed during a one-to-one consultation and was developed with input from diabetes healthcare professionals and people with diabetes. The participant was encouraged to progress through the workbook individually at home. Topics included types of physical activity, intensity for health benefits, physical activity importance, identifying and overcoming reasons not to be active, current physical activity, the amount of activity to undertake, opportunities for activity, social support, preventing relapse and developing goals. The physical activity pack also included a pedometer, a 12-week walking plan and a guide to local physical activity opportunities. Fact sheets on foot care, checking blood glucose levels and finding further information about diabetes were included.
At 6 months, participants were given one of two workbooks based on their progress over the previous 6 months. Participants in the action or maintenance stage of physical activity behaviour change were given a workbook to strengthen current behaviour, which included topics such as reviewing progress, reasons to stay more active, physical activity importance for short-and long-term health, relapse prevention, staying challenged and motivated. Participants who relapsed or were still not achieving physical activity recommendations were given a workbook which reinforced information given at baseline.

At baseline, participants received a two-page information leaflet titled 'Exercise and Your Diabetes' by the Tayside Diabetes Network. It is given as part of standard treatment for people with Type 2 diabetes and is available online (http://taysidedn. dundee.ac.uk/Documents/Uploaded/DiabetesandExercise.pdf). At 6 months, a one-page leaflet taken from the Diabetes UK website was used to suggest activities to undertake.

Each participant received follow-up phone calls at 1 and 3 months after both baseline and 6-month visits lasting 5-10 min. For participants in both intervention groups, this provided an opportunity to discuss their physical activity plan and barriers experienced. Physical activity was not discussed with participants in the standard care group.
Qualitative research on participant adherence and views of the physical activity interventions has been previously published.

Statistical power was calculated using a pedometer step count standard deviation of 16 000 steps ⁄ week and true difference of 15 000 steps ⁄ week (equivalent to adding 3000 steps ⁄ day or approximately a 30-min walk ⁄ day, 5 days of the week). With an 80% power and 5% significance level (90% power and 2.5% significance level were used for calculations to allow for making two main comparisons) a minimum of 29 people are required in each group for final analysis. An excess of this number will allow for dropout, missing data and ⁄ or greater power. The Robertson Centre for Biostatistics (Glasgow, Scotland) provided statistical guidance.

Dropout from the study was around 10% (in person delivered and standard care) with slightly higher rates (17%) recorded in the written delivered group. Data were analysed using intention to treat. Missing data as a result of dropout after randomization were imputed by carrying forward responses from baseline.

Accelerometer wear-time compliance and cleaning was conducted for each participant by comparing times worn on the ActiGraph monitor with a weekly diary of sleeping and waking hours based on recommendations for handling missing data. A week with more than 3 days missing was invalid and not used in any analyses. A full day included at least 10 h of wear time. If wear time was less than 10 h or more than 6 h were missing, the day was voided and an average from the remaining week was imputed for that day. An average was imputed for missing data from 2 to 6 h.
Analysis spss 15.0 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA) was used for all analyses. Physical activity data from the 7-day recall were analysed and reported as a combination of moderate intensity and above. This was carried out because of the limited amount of vigorous activity done by study participants and to reflect the current physical activity guidelines. A 3 • 3 way (time • group) repeated-measures anova was used to test the effect of the interventions on continuous outcome measures. Significant main effects were analysed with adjustments made for multiple comparisons. The v 2 -test was used to analyse medication.

No significant between-group differences were found at baseline on any measured outcome variable. At baseline, those who dropped out (n = 18) were similar in age, employment status and levels of physical activity, but had significantly higher BMI, HbA 1c and socio-economic deprivation (P < 0.05).

Table illustrates the change in physical activity outcomes over the study period. The relationship between objective and subjective physical activity data from this study has previously been published.
There was no significant interaction between time and group on HbA 1c , total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, waist circumference, BMI, systolic blood pressure or diastolic blood pressure.

There was a significant main effect of time on accelerometer counts (P < 0.001), step counts (P = 0.005), time in moderate intensity or above (P = 0.006) and the 7-day recall (P = 0.007), with an overall decrease between baseline and 12 months (P < 0.01) and 6 and 12 months (P < 0.01) across all measures of physical activity.

There was no main effect of group in accelerometer counts (P = 0.061), step counts (P = 0.066), time in moderate intensity or above (P = 0.104) or the 7-day recall (P = 0.371).
Table documents the changes in physical activity in a subgroup of the total sample selected for having baseline pedometer steps less than 5000 steps per day. Analysis of this subgroup identified significant interaction effects for accelerometer counts and pedometer counts. Pairwise comparisons documented a significant increase in the physical activity consultation group delivered by a person from baseline to 12 months (P < 0.05) and a significant decrease in the control group from baseline to 12 months (P < 0.001) and 6 to 12 months (P < 0.001) in both accelerometer and pedometer counts. No significant changes were seen in the group receiving the physical activity consultation in written form.
Additional subgroup analysis was conducted on the change in physical activity level (objective and subjective measures) in participants above and below the mean duration of diabetes (14.4 years). No differences in results were found.
Table illustrates the results of all physiological and biochemical outcomes over the study period.

A significant main effect of time was found on HbA 1c (P = 0.026), total cholesterol (P = 0.001), HDL cholesterol (P = 0.029), waist circumference (P = 0.020), systolic blood pressure (P = 0.037) and diastolic blood pressure (P = 0.001).
There was no main effect of time on BMI (P = 0.344). HbA 1c significantly decreased between baseline and 6 months and significantly increased between 6 and 12 months (P < 0.05). Significant decreases from baseline to 12 months and from 6 to 12 months were seen in total cholesterol, waist circumference and systolic and diastolic blood pressure (P < 0.05). HDL cholesterol decreased only from baseline to 12 months (P < 0.05).

Neither a theory-driven physical activity consultation delivered by a person nor in written form were better than a standard care leaflet at increasing physical activity levels over 6 and 12 months in the full study group of people with Type 2 diabetes. These results were consistent across all measures of physical activity. As no increase in physical activity was evident, improvements in physiological and biochemical measures were not expected, although improvements in total and HDL cholesterol, systolic and diastolic blood pressure and waist circumference were seen overtime in the full study sample over 12 months and in glycaemic control at 6 months. As many participants were newly diagnosed, it is likely they were able to achieve these improvements overtime with appropriate guidance, diet and medication following routine diabetes check-ups. Tighter cholesterol targets were also released for people with Type 2 diabetes during data collection. These factors made it more difficult to detect any change that may have occurred from our intervention.
The Time2Act was a well-designed study which included attributes known to be most effective in physical activity but it failed to show a significant increase in physical activity. In fact, a significant decrease was seen across all groups from 6 to 12 months. Dropout from the study was approximately 10% (in person delivered and standard care), with slightly higher rates (17%) in the written delivered group. The findings of this study are similar to results found in the ProActive UK trial. This larger trial promoted physical activity in adults at risk for Type 2 diabetes by comparing two theory-based interventions: a person-delivered and telephonedelivered intervention compared with a control group. They too found no improvements in physical activity levels or cardiorespiratory fitness over 12 months and suggested that more inclusive public health strategies are needed which take into account socio-cultural and environmental influences on physical activity.
Results from Time2Act, however, are in contrast to other studies using a similar physical activity consultation method in people in Type 2 diabetes [3,9,10]. All three studies found an increase in physical activity and clinically meaningful improvements in HbA 1c . It is possible that our participants were healthier, indicative through physiological and biochemical parameters. In addition, they may have been more physically active to begin with. This is also likely, given average baseline levels of activity were over 6000 steps ⁄ day and 152 min of at least moderate activity which meets American College of Sports Medicine (ACSM) guidelines for health benefits of 150 min of moderate intensity activity ⁄ week. The group receiving a physical activity consultation delivered by a person was the most active at baseline with 6415 steps ⁄ day and 178 min of moderate activity ⁄ week. The success of the interventions maybe affected by baseline activity levels. Subgroup analysis of change in physical activity with Time2ACT participants who had a baseline step countless than 5000 steps ⁄ day identified significant interaction effects in total accelerometer counts and total pedometer counts, with pairwise comparisons revealing the physical activity consultation group delivered by a person to have significantly increased from baseline to 12 months and the standard care group to have significantly decreased from baseline to months and from 6 to 12 months. The physical activity consultation delivered in written form recorded no change. The goal of our interventions was to increase physical activity to meet ACSM health recommendations. This was possibly the wrong focus fora number of participants. Increasing the duration or intensity of activity to prevent weight gain and ⁄ or improve fitness would have been a more appropriate focus for these relatively active participants.
Recruitment methods may have influenced the make-up of our relatively active study sample. This study relied heavily on media advertisements for volunteers rather than the sole recruitment through routine diabetes clinics. We found that using the media for volunteers attracted people who were more physically active or, conversely, just wanted to support a cause with no real interest in doing more physical activity. Future research should carefully consider the best method of recruitment.
There were notable changes between the current study and prior work of Kirk et al. in the delivery of the consultation. The current study used a structured format, with the workbook as a guide to ensure similar content between intervention groups. Prior research had no formalized workbook, only a discussion of cognitive behavioural strategies coupled with the transtheoretical model as an overarching guide. Perhaps visibly using a workbook created a less person-centered experience for the participant.
The location of consultation delivery in the study may have been a contributing factor as consultations were carried out at a university sports centre. Successful studies have delivered consultations in a medical setting, perhaps providing a feeling of legitimacy and medical endorsement with participants [3,. This is again supported by the ProActive UK trial which also found no change in physical activity levels after conducting a similar person-delivered intervention at participants' homes.
In summary, physical activity is a critical component of diabetes management which is underutilized at the individual level and under promoted in routine diabetes care. More research is needed not only to investigate the most economical and effective methods to promote physical activity, but also on the best setting to conduct physical activity consultations and the factors that may affect uptake of physical activity in diabetes care.
